title: Discover Ohio’s Hidden Apple Gems
text:
The goal of this website is to share data collected at The Ohio State University on the traits of Ohio apples valuable to local growers.
Whether you’re an apple grower seeking to diversify your orchard or a curious eater eager to explore new flavors, this resource highlights Ohio’s unique apple offerings.
Select ‘About’ at the top to learn more, or ‘Apples’ to choose an apple to learn more about.
We would love to hear from you! Click here to provide feedback or email balogh.67@osu.edu

title: Sweet Maia
text:
Early season apple that is deep red in color. Released by the Midwest Apple Improvement Association.






 Ripe apple flavor with honey and earthy notes, with a hint of grassiness.





Relative size

title: Scruffy
text:
Imperfect skin color and appearance (looks ‘Scruffy’) but a dense, crispy, juicy apple. Late mid-season. Released by the Midwest Apple Improvement Association.






Medium-high in crispness and juiciness, with medium sweetness and sourness. Consumers on average like this apple, especially the texture, but less-so the appearance.


 

Relative size

title: Rosalee
text:
A cross of Honeycrisp x Fuji. Late mid-season apple. Released by the Midwest Apple Improvement Association.






An apple high in juiciness and crispness, with medium-high sweetness, and medium sourness, with apple, grassy flavor. Consumers on average like this apple, especially the texture.


 

Relative size

title: Plum Delicious
text:
A purplish-blushed apple with interesting flavor combination. Ripens late season. Excellent keeping. Released by Rutgers University.






An medium-high in crispness and sweetness, medium in juiciness and sourness, with ripe apple, earthy, honey, grassy, fruity flavor. Consumers on average highly like this apple.


 

Relative size

title: MDW 20-100
text:
An attractive red apple that ripens mid-season. Released by the Midwest Apple Improvement Association.






An apple medium-high in sweetness, juiciness, and crispness, and low in sourness, with ripe apple, honey, grassy, and floral flavor. Consumers on average like this apple.


 

Relative size

title: Kindercrisp
text:
Ripens early season. Honeycrisp is one parent. Released by a private breeder in Minnesota.






An apple medium-high in crispness, juiciness, and sweetness, with low sourness, with ripe apple, grassy, honey, and earthy flavor. Consumers on average like this apple.


 

Relative size

title: Golden Russet
text:
An old American variety with rich flavors. Russet skin finish.






An apple high in crispness, with medium sweetness, sourness, and juiciness, with grassy, apple, earthy, and honey flavor. Consumers on average like this apple a medium amount, but like the appearance less.


 

Relative size

title: Evercrisp
text:
A cross of Honeycrisp x Fuji. Late season ripening. Released by the Midwest Apple Improvement Association. Keeps crisp for months.






An apple high in crispness and juiciness, with medium sweetness and low sourness, with apple, flavor. Consumers on average highly like this apple.


 

Relative size

title: Crimson Crisp
text:
Very pretty red apple. Ripens mid-season. Released from Purdue-Rutgers-Illinois breeding program.







An apple high in crispness, medium in juiciness and sweetness, and low in sourness, with ripe apple, grassy, earthy flavor. Consumers on average highly like this apple.



 

Relative size

title: All Apples
text:
See how the apples compare against each other!

  Note that even apples that trend towards lower liking still have some consumers ranking it in the high range. Everyone has different tastes, some of these lower-ranked apples may fit a niche taste that some consumers really value!

title: About
text:
Purpose This website is for sharing the findings of extensive food sensory testing conducted on 30+ apple selections. Our goal is to provide information on the taste, flavor, and texture attributes of these apples, focusing on varieties that hold particular relevance for Ohio growers and consumers. Unlike the more familiar apples commonly found in grocery stores, these selections include unique and lesser-known varieties. We aim to educate and inspire both growers and consumers, showcasing the diverse and flavorful apple options well-suited to growth Ohio.
What is food sensory evaluation? Sensory evaluation uses humans as instruments to analyze the sensory properties of foods, drinks, and other consumer products. Using these techniques, we were able to evaluate the taste, aroma, flavor, and texture of the apples in this project. We were also able to gain insights into what aspects of these apples consumers like.
For more information about the food sensory testing, please select Descriptive Analysis or Consumer Testing in the header drop-down menu under ‘About.’
Research team Dr. Jessica Cooperstone, Dr. Diane Miller, Dr. Jonathan Fresnedo Ramírez, Dr. Chris Simons, and hard-working graduate students (Lydia Balogh, MS, and others) at The Ohio State University.
This project was sponsored by the Ohio Department of Agriculture (ODA, award AM22SCBPOH1157) Specialty Block Grant and the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA, award 2023-67013-40267) and supported by the Midwest Apple Foundation (MAF). We thank the many Ohio and midwestern apple growers who have provided apples for our studies.

title: Consumer Testing
text:
Consumer testing (also known as hedonic testing) is a sensory technique where panelists are asked to taste food samples and rate them on a scale on how much they liked the sample.
For the apple consumer testing, we had regular consumers of apples come in and try slices of the apple selections. They rated appearance liking, flavor liking, texture liking, and overall liking on a 9-point scale. The 9-point scale ranged from 1, “dislike extremely,” to 9, “like extremely.”


   Pictured: how an apple slice is presented to a consumer in the tasting booth.

title: Descriptive Analysis
text:
Descriptive analysis is a sensory technique where trained judges are used to collect a complete sensory profile of a product. The product is broken down into its individual taste, flavor, and texture attributes. In the case of apples, that includes traits like sweetness, honey flavor, and crispness.
The judges use physical references as guides to calibrate their taste to an intensity scale from 1-10. For example, to measure crispness, a low score (1) was referenced by a canned pear slice. A high score (10) was referenced by a fresh piece of celery.
Descriptive analysis provides us with objective descriptions of the traits of the apples in this study.
Our descriptive analysis panel was also asked to identify flavors using a ‘check-all-that-apply’ model. The flavors all corresponded to references, but were measured on presence rather than overall intensity. For example, ‘apple’ flavor was compared to pressed apple cider, while ‘grassy’ flavor was compared to the aroma of fresh-cut grass.


   Pictured: apple descriptive analysis taking place.

A late season crispy juicy yellow apple.






An apple high in juiciness and low in sourness, with grassy, apple flavor. Consumers on average highly like this apple, but like the appearance less.


 

Relative size

title: Amarillo
text:
A cross of Honeycrisp x Fuji. Ripens early mid-season. Released by the Midwest Apple Improvement Association.






An apple high in juiciness with medium crispness and sweetness and low sourness, with grassy, apple flavor. Consumers on average like this apple, especially its texture.


 

Relative size

title: Crunch-a-Bunch
text:
An early October yellow apple.






An apple high in crispness and juiciness, with medium sourness and sweetness, with grassy, apple flavor. Consumers on average like this apple, especially its texture.


 

Relative size

title: Gala
text:
High quality standard apple available world-wide. Used as a comparative standard in our work.






An apple medium in crispness, juiciness, sweetness, and sourness, with grassy, apple flavor. Consumers on average like this apple a medium amount, and especially like the appearance.


 

Relative size

title: GoldRush
text:
Apple that is full of flavors. Late season ripening. Released from Purdue-Rutgers-Illinois breeding program.






An apple high in crispness, with medium juiciness, sweetness, and sourness, with grassy, apple flavor. Consumers on average like this apple.


 

Relative size

title: Ludacrisp
text:
Ripens mid-October. Full of flavors. Released by the Midwest Apple Improvement Association.






An apple medium-high in juiciness and crispness, and medium sweetness and sourness, with ripe apple, grassy, earthy flavor. Consumers on average like this apple, especially the texture.


 

Relative size

title: Pixie Crunch
text:
Bright red, crisp apple that ripens mid-season. Can be larger sized than its name suggests. Released by the Purdue-Rutgers-Illinois breeding program.






An apple medium-high in crispness, medium in juiciness and sweetness, and low in sourness, with ripe apple, grassy, and earthy flavor. Consumers on average like this apple, especially the texture.


 

Relative size

title: Premier Honeycrisp
text:
An early season ripening strain of Honeycrisp. Discovered by a grower in Honeycrisp block of trees.






An apple high in crispness and juiciness, medium sweetness and sourness, with apple, grassy, honey, earthy flavor. Consumers on average highly like this apple.


 

Relative size

title: Sansa
text:
An early season apple with interesting skin color and flavor.






An apple medium-high in sweetness, with medium juiciness, and low crispness and sourness, with ripe apple, honey, grassy, fruity, earthy flavor. Consumers on average like this apple a medium amount, and especially like the appearance.


 

Relative size

title: Summerset
text:
A cross of Honeycrisp x Fuji. Early September apple. Released by Midwest Apple Improvement Association.






An apple medium-high in juiciness, crispness, and medium sourness, with ripe apple, honey, grassy, earthy, and caramel flavor. Consumers on average like this apple.


 

Relative size

title: Zestar
text:
Early season apple. Released by the University of Minnesota.






An apple medium in juiciness, sweetness, and sourness, low in crispness, with ripe apple, honey, grassy, warm spice, and earthy flavor. Consumers on average like this apple, especially the appearance, but less-so the texture.


 

Relative size
